TextView.android:text: Although Greco-Roman astronomer Ptolemy (90â€“168) identified a place called Sabana in the general area,the earliest written record of Singapore occurs in a Chinese account from the third century, describing the island of Pu Luo Chung.The Sejarah Melayu (Malay Annals) contains a tale of a prince of Srivijaya, Sri Tri Buana (also known as Sang Nila Utama), who landed on the island during the 13th century. When he saw a lion, the prince took this as an auspicious sign and founded a settlement called Singapura, which means 'Lion City' in Malay.
